content.title: AC vs DC: What's the Difference?
content.content:
**Direct Current (DC)**
DC flows in **one direction only**, from positive to negative, continuously. Think of a battery — the current always flows the same way through your circuit.

**Common DC sources:**
- Batteries (AA, car battery, phone battery)
- Solar panels
- DC power supplies
- USB chargers (output DC even though they plug into AC mains)

**Alternating Current (AC)**
AC **reverses direction** periodically. It flows forward, then backward, then forward again, in a continuous cycle. The electrons don't travel far — they just vibrate back and forth.

**Common AC sources:**
- Mains electricity (wall sockets)
- Generators in power stations
- Car alternators

**Why use AC for mains?**
- **Easy to transform**: AC voltage can be easily stepped up or down using transformers
- **Efficient transmission**: High voltage AC loses less energy over long distances
- **Easy to generate**: Power stations naturally produce AC from rotating generators

**Key Point:** Although AC reverses direction, we still measure it in amps (A) and volts (V), just like DC. But AC has an extra property: **frequency**.

content.title: Understanding Frequency
content.content:
**What is Frequency?**
Frequency measures **how many times per second** the current completes a full cycle (forward-backward-forward). It's measured in **hertz (Hz)**.

**1 Hz = 1 cycle per second**

**UK Mains Frequency: 50 Hz**
This means:
- The current reverses direction 100 times per second (50 cycles × 2 directions)
- One complete cycle takes 1/50 = 0.02 seconds (20 milliseconds)

**Why 50 Hz?**
- Historical standard in the UK and most of Europe, Africa, Asia, Australia
- Works well with the power grid and electrical equipment
- Different countries use different frequencies:
  - **UK, Europe, most of world:** 50 Hz
  - **USA, parts of Americas:** 60 Hz

**At Level 2, you don't need to:**
- Calculate waveforms or use sine/cosine
- Work with peak voltages vs RMS
- Analyze phase angles

**You DO need to know:**
- UK mains is 50 Hz
- Frequency is measured in hertz (Hz)
- 50 Hz means 50 cycles per second
- AC alternates, DC doesn't

content.title: UK Mains Supply Characteristics
content.content:
**Standard UK Mains Supply:**
- **Voltage:** 230 V (volts)
- **Frequency:** 50 Hz (hertz)
- **Type:** Single-phase AC

**What does 230V mean?**
This is the **nominal voltage** — the standard voltage supplied to homes and most buildings. It can vary slightly (e.g., 220V to 240V is acceptable), but we call it 230V.

**Historical Note:**
Older installations may have been rated at 240V. The UK adopted the European standard of 230V, but the actual voltage didn't change much — equipment rated for 240V still works fine.

**Wiring Colors (Important for Safety):**
- **Live (L):** Brown wire — carries the AC voltage
- **Neutral (N):** Blue wire — return path (near 0V)
- **Earth (E):** Green/Yellow striped — safety connection (0V)

**Safety Notes:**
- Mains AC at 230V is **dangerous** and can be fatal
- Always isolate circuits before working on them
- Never work on live mains equipment unless qualified
- Use appropriate PPE and follow regulations

**Common Mains-Powered Devices:**
- Lighting circuits
- Household appliances (kettles, TVs, washing machines)
- Power tools
- Heating systems

content.title: Worked Example: AC Characteristics
content.given: A device is rated for "230V AC, 50 Hz". Explain what each part means.

steps.description: Identify the voltage rating: 230V. This is the nominal operating voltage. The device is designed to work with UK mains supply voltage.
Identify the current type: AC. This means the current alternates direction. The device requires AC, not DC. It won't work properly on a 230V DC supply.
Identify the frequency: 50 Hz. This means 50 cycles per second. This is the UK standard frequency. Some equipment is frequency-sensitive (like clocks or motors).

Conclusion: This device is designed for UK mains supply. Plug it into a standard UK wall socket and it will work correctly. Don't use it in countries with different voltage/frequency without a transformer.
steps.result: Device compatible with UK mains (230V, 50Hz AC)

content.notes: Always check device ratings before connecting to power. Using wrong voltage or wrong current type (AC vs DC) can damage equipment or create safety hazards.

content.title: Guided Practice (We Do)
content.problem: You have a 12V DC battery and a 230V AC mains socket. Compare these two supplies.

steps.prompt: Does the battery supply AC or DC?
steps.hint: Batteries always supply current in one direction only.

steps.prompt: Does the mains socket supply AC or DC?
steps.hint: Wall sockets in homes supply alternating current.

steps.prompt: What is the frequency of the DC battery supply?
steps.hint: DC doesn't alternate, so it has no frequency (0 Hz).

steps.prompt: What is the frequency of the UK mains socket?
steps.hint: UK mains frequency is a standard value you need to memorize.

steps.prompt: Which voltage is safer to work with: 12V or 230V?
steps.hint: Lower voltages are generally safer. 230V mains can be fatal.
